abstract: Some owners of private New York City properties that are open to public close spaces annually to protect themselves against any possible claim of 'adverse possession,' a concept with ancient roots; concept holds that if someone uses property for a long period without being challenged by the owner, the property becomes that of the user.
snippet: Owners of some properties close them annually to protect themselves against any possible claim of “adverse possession,” a concept with ancient roots.
lead_paragraph: Owners of some properties close them annually to protect themselves against any possible claim of “adverse possession,” a concept with ancient roots.

headline.main: Closing for a Spell, Just to Prove It’s Ours
headline.print_headline: Closing for a Spell, Just to Prove It’s Ours
headline.seo: Lever House Closes Once a Year to Maintain Its Ownership Rights
